content: How can I help you today?

I'm not even sure where to start. My wife and I have been struggling at home, mainly because our son has been acting out a lot. It's been overwhelming, and honestly, it feels like everything is falling apart.

That sounds like a really heavy experience for you and your family. It can be incredibly overwhelming to manage challenges at home, especially when it feels like so much is happening all at once. What has been the hardest part of all this for you?
I think the hardest part is feeling like I’m failing as a parent and a husband. No matter what I do, I can’t seem to help my son or fix things with my wife. It’s draining, and I feel stuck.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot on your shoulders right now, between trying to support your son and nurture your relationship with your wife. Feeling like you're not able to "fix" things must be so disheartening, especially when you're giving so much of yourself. What has helped you keep going despite feeling this way?

Honestly, I’m not sure. I guess I just keep going because I feel like I have to—for my son, my wife, and even my daughter. But it’s getting harder to keep it together, and I don’t know how much more I can take staying in this place.

It’s clear how deeply you care about your family and how committed you are to being there for them, even when things feel so overwhelming. You’re shouldering a lot for the people you love, and it’s understandable that you’re feeling drained. What do you think would need to change for things to start feeling a little less heavy?

I don’t even know where to start. I guess I wish I knew how to help my son behave better or how to connect with my wife again, but it feels like those answers are so far out of reach. Maybe if I didn’t feel so helpless all the time, things would feel lighter.

It sounds like feeling stuck and unsure of what to do has been weighing you down the most. Wanting to help your son and reconnect with your wife shows just how deeply you value your family and how much you care about making things better. What do you think has been getting in the way of finding those answers or feeling less helpless?

I guess it’s that everything feels like it’s too much at once. My son’s behavior is a constant focus, and my wife and I barely have time or energy left to even talk about how we’re feeling. It’s like I don’t even know what steps to take or where to put my attention first. It’s all just tangled up.

It sounds like you’re caught in this cycle where everything feels urgent and overwhelming, and it’s hard to know where to begin. It’s a tough place to be, but acknowledging how much you’re juggling is really important. If you could focus on just one small thing to start with, what feels like it might make the biggest difference right now?

I guess if I could just figure out how to connect with my son, that might make it feel a little less chaotic. But honestly, I don’t even know where to begin with that—I’ve tried talking to him, disciplining him, giving him space, and nothing seems to work. It's exhausting.

It sounds like you’ve already tried so many things to connect with your son, which really shows how determined you are to improve things. Even though it’s been exhausting, you haven’t given up on trying. When you think about the moments when you do connect with him, if even just a little, are there any small things that seem to bring you closer?

It’s hard to even think of a moment like that lately. He’s been so angry and distant, and every time I try to connect, it feels like I make things worse. I don’t know what he needs from me, and I’m starting to feel like I’m failing him completely.

It sounds like you’re really feeling the weight of wanting to be there for your son but not knowing how. That sense of wanting so badly to understand him while feeling like he’s slipping farther away must be incredibly difficult to sit with. If you were able to imagine his perspective for just a moment, what do you think he might be hoping for from you right now, even if he’s not showing it?

I think he might just need to feel heard or understood, but it’s hard to tell when he shuts me out or lashes out. Maybe he wants support but doesn’t know how to ask for it, or maybe he’s angry about something I’m not seeing. I honestly don’t know, and it’s frustrating.

It sounds like you're really trying to make sense of where your son might be coming from, even though it’s not entirely clear to you yet. You’re showing a lot of empathy and insight by considering that he might just need to feel heard or supported. How do you think you might be able to start creating moments where he could feel more comfortable opening up to you?

I'm not sure. Maybe I could try talking to him without pressing too hard or making it about solving things. Just letting him talk, if he even wants to. But honestly, I worry that even if I try that, he won’t respond, and we’ll end up back in the same frustrated place.

It makes sense that you'd worry about trying something new and still feeling stuck—that’s a tough place to be. But thinking about creating space for him to talk without pressure shows a lot of thoughtfulness. Even if he doesn’t respond right away, it could still be a step toward showing him that you’re there for him, no matter what. How would it feel to take that small step, even with the uncertainty?

It would feel like a risk, honestly. I'd want it to work and show some progress, but if it doesn't, I'm not sure how much more rejection or frustration I can handle. I know I should probably try, though—it’s just hard to feel hopeful right now.

Taking that step when you’re already feeling uncertain and worn down does feel risky, and it’s completely understandable to feel hesitant. The fact that you’re still considering trying shows how much you care and are willing to keep moving forward for your son and your family. Is there anything that might help you feel a little more supported as you think about taking that step?
